Ravi Karunanayake) The posts of Vice-Chancellor and Dean of the University of Vocational Technology which comes under the Minister of Vocational and Technical Training should have been filled by the 1st of October, but still it has not been done and as a result, the entire operations of the university have come to a standstill. The Government wanted one year to fill those vacancies. Hon. Minister, you have been very keen about this. - [Interruption.] I know that, but you have a wide knowledge on the university system.
. . ( . . ) (The Hon. (Prof.) W.A. Wiswa Warnapala) I can intervene in the matter but it does not come under my purview.

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Really, this should have been brought under your purview, but it is under the Minister of Vocational and Technical Training. You should take it under you because for one year these posts have not been filled. I think Prof. Dayasiri was instrumental in getting this university.
. . ( . . ) (The Hon. (Prof.) W.A. Wiswa Warnapala) Hon. Member, I cannot take a decision on that matter. Let me consult His Excellency the President and see what could be done.
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) It is this same university which has given doctorates to the President and the Secretary of Defence.

, Super James? I do not think he is the "Super James". He is the Leader of the Opposition, whom we respect, though we differ. But, who is this "Super James" from Las Vegas, you are talking about? ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake)
Do you think only the kings are super? Do you think only the Rajjuruvos are super? ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
Is he from Las Vegas night clubs? ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake)
These are our supers. So, do not worry about that. We will ensure that at the right time, the right things will happen. Now, why do you not, as the Minister -
Sad that you all will end up in a supper. That is what will happen.
Okay. Now, Hon. Minister, leave the supper and the dessert to us. ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
Why do you not provide the answer to my Question? ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
I ask for one weeks time to answer this Question. ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake)

This is a travesty of justice, Hon. Minister. You are unable to respond. You cannot present a Budget in this House. You cannot say from what country monies come from and you also have the audacity to ask for more time.
I think a better advice was given by the Hon. Choksy who is a Presidents Counsel yesterday. Why do you not listen to his advice? He is a former Minister of Finance.

If you only want to listen to what is corrected and if that is put forward, it does not matter. But, you only want to prop up the Government opinion. Now, yesterday how bankrupt were you? The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva, as a Minister, was winding up his speech by using the Hon. Choksys statement. What he did not say was the truth, the most important. It was only the doctored version that you wanted to say, and that was what was told. That was the difference. Three days ago we spoke about the Fiscal Management (Responsibility) Act. By now you have forgotten what was in it.
The UNP argument for three days was bowled by him in just two minutes. That was what happened yesterday. . . Question ordered to stand down.

: : , ACCESS FACILITIES FOR DISABLED CITIZENS INTO GOVERNMENT BUILDINGS : STATEMENT BY MINISTER OF SOCIAL SERVICES AND SOCIAL WELFARE ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena) , .

. , . , . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) ? ( ) (The Hon. Bimal Ratnayake) . ? ( ) (Mr. Speaker) . ( ) (The Hon. Bimal Ratnayake) , . . , ? ? ( ) (The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva) . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) . ? ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) , 25 . I now quote from today's "The Island" newspaper which states: Rohithas claim on Andaman Island wrong - Govt." , . Hon. Speaker, I quote "The Island" of 6th November, 2009: An authoritative government official last night told The Island that there was absolutely no basis for Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagamas claim that Indias Andaman Island would come within the area which Sri Lanka was hoping to claim, in keeping with its sea bed rights, from the UN Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf.

Foreign Minister Rohitha Bogollagama on Wednesday (Nov 4) told Parliament that Sri Lankas claim would be discussed with India before making final submissions to the UN Commission. He was responding to a query raised by UNP MP Ravi Karunanayake. The Minister said that Sri Lanka had a right to claim approximately around 25 times the size of the countrys land mass (1,725,800 square kilometers of the seabed.) The official said that Sri Lanka submitted its claim to the UN on May 8 this year in New York. Responding to our queries, he said that under no circumstances could Sri Lanka ever claim any part of Indian territory in the Andaman sea region, let alone the Andaman itself. I am sorry, Hon. Minister, I did not see you when I raised the point.
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Rohitha Bogollagama - Minister of Foreign Affairs)
That is all right. You go ahead.

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) The Island newspaper of today carries this article. At that particular moment I did confess that my knowledge on that subject is not superior. Hon. Minister, there is a Government source disputing the statement made by you in Parliament. So, I would like you to make a full statement with a clarification before this House as to why we would not be able to enjoy this right which should be bestowed on us by 1st of January, 2011. Is this also an international conspiracy?

Hon. Speaker, I am extremely happy that my learned and good Friend, the Hon. Ravi Karunanayake raised this matter. In fact, I was thinking of raising that as a matter of Privilege because todays The Island newspaper has stated, "An authoritative government official" but they have not mentioned the name. I was wondering who said this because they have failed to state the name of the official or any other person of the Government who has disputed what I stated on the Floor of this House the day before yesterday. Therefore, it is irresponsible journalism that has been practised by this particular newspaper from which the Hon. Ravi Karunanayake has quoted. I now wonder for a moment whether this is a plan to raise this matter before the August Assembly today. I stand by what I have stated the day before yesterday, that we have submitted our claim in terms of the Legal Continental Shelf, properly and at the right time to the authorities concerned.

Secondly, we are not going to claim any Indian territory unless we negotiate in terms of the seabed rights, even if it is touching some of our boundaries. This is what I stated very clearly and emphatically the day before yesterday; that if there are any boundaries that are touching or overlapping one another, that will be a matter for bilateral negotiations between India and Sri Lanka. I stand by what I said and would like The Island newspaper to correct the statement that they have published and I would seek a direction from the Hon. Speaker to the newspaper concerned to reflect correctly what I have stated on the Floor of this House. Thank you. ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake)

Hon. Speaker, that is only a reflection of what the Hon. Minister stated in Parliament. As I stated on Wednesday, 4th of November, Sri Lanka has definitely lost the opportunity to obtain this right by 2011. Hon. Minister, I read your statement. There is no clarification given as to why it has been postponed for year 2025. I am telling you with all sincerity, that this particular right put on the basis of urgency for Sri Lanka, is lost. Is this a part of an international conspiracy that your Government has always been speaking of ? ( ) (The Hon. Rohitha Bogollagama)

Hon. Member, you are just adding words to your very valid statement. Only you know of conspiracies, because if at all, any conspiracy is to be hatched, it will come only from the Opposition and maybe from the untruths that you utter. But, I do not want to attribute anything to the United National Party in this regard because it will be a personal comment on my learned Friend who is capable of making such comments. At the same time, Sir, we applied at the correct time and why it is now listed to be granted in the year 2025, after 15 years, is because there are so many other applications as well. Therefore, we will never get this right by 2011 as stated by the Hon. Member, because there are so many countries seeking determination on seabed rights from the authorities concerned. Our application will stand and when it will be taken up for hearing, we will be sending a special team to canvass for the priority areas embodied in our application. -[Interruption.] . [ ] , 2011 . 2009 application - [ ] ( )
( - ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe - Leader of the Opposition)
Hon. Minister, since this is an important issue, can you make a full statement before the House when we meet on the 17th of November?

Now that the Hon. Leader of the Opposition has sought a full statement from me, I will be very happy to submit a detailed account on the submission that we have already made, and I will reiterate what I have stated the day before yesterday as well. Thank you, Sir.

Hon. Deputy Speaker, we are once again debating the extension of the state of Emergency in November, 2009. This is, Sir, after the war has come to an end, after the armed conflict in the country has come to an end and in a situation where the causes that were urged in the past for a declaration and continuance of the Emergency, that is the war or the armed conflict, no longer exist and no longer justify the declaration or the continuance of the state of Emergency. I would say with great respect, Sir, that the Emergency is being used to suspend the countrys nor-mal laws which exist for the benefit of the citizens of the country, which confer upon citizens several rights in re-gard to their lives and it would be my submission, that that is wrong by any standard of judgement to continue to extend the state of Emergency when the reasons that ex-isted in the past for its promulgation have come to an end and that the Emergency, therefore, is obnoxious and unac-ceptable. Sir, having made those comments briefly in regard to the state of Emergency, I would use the little time I have at my disposal in the course of this Debate to deal with certain fundamental issues pertaining to the internally displaced people who numbered about 300,000 originally and who were confined to various internment camps or detention camps against their will and in violation of the domestic and international laws. The Government, Sir, was rigid in regard to the denial of movement to these people, in regard to the denial of access to the IDPs by other persons, whether they were friends, relatives, well-wishers, other civilians or the media personnel who were engaged in relief work and so on and so forth. With the denial of access to the IDPs to meet with others, the per-sons who were internally displaced were being kept with-out any contact whatever with anyone else. They had numerous other difficulties in regard to food, medicine, drinking water, sanitation and shelter. These persons have suffered immensely during the period that they were kept in these camps, in detention or interned. It would appear, Sir, from reports that have been com-ing out recently, that about 100,000 people or a little more

have come out of the camps or been released from the camps. Almost yet another 200,000 people or a little less still remain in the camps. They are being detained against their will and in violation of domestic and international laws. That is the true position which no one can deny. Everyone, including the United Nations and the interna-tional community, has unanimously demanded that this detention must be brought to an end. In fact, I believe the US Congress, the US Parliament has recently passed a resolution, the headlines of which I read in the newspa-pers this morning, -

. ( . ) (The Hon. R. Sampanthan) Venerable Presiding Member, if I might repeat my last sentence, I observed in the newspapers this morning that, in fact, the US Congress has passed a resolution that all persons who are being detained or interned in these camps must be released forthwith and at the earliest. This is not merely the view of the UN, but also the view of the European Union and the international community. It is even the view of India that these detentions must be brought to an end; that these people be granted the free-dom to make their own decision in regard to their future and once they make the decision, they be provided with the required facilities to be able to implement their deci-9 - PL 004589 - (2009/11)

sion. They should be able to decide whether they want to join their relatives, their friends, go and live with a host family or whether they would like to be accommodated in some transient centres in their respective districts, from which they can have access to their lands, their damaged properties and resuscitate those properties and whatever left of their buildings, to be in a position to commence their occupation at the earliest. If that is possible, if there are no mines in that area, they should be able to think in terms of being able to commence their employment activi-ties. If none of them were detained and interned in these camps in Vavuniya, if they were at transit camps or tran-sient camps set up in their respective districts, it would be much easier for the people to go to those camps and make preparations for them to commence life. That right, Venerable Presiding Member, is being de-nied to these people. They are being detained by force; they are being denied the rights which normal citizens of this country are entitled to and that is something which is totally unacceptable, particularly given the fact that very shortly there is a possibility that these people may have the opportunity to exercise their franchise at elections, and their franchise is a part of their sovereignty. These people being detained in camps in this way, whether it be in Va-vuniya or even in the present transit camps in the districts to which they have moved out, in which I am told, some-times the conditions are even worse than the conditions in Vavuniya, is not acceptable. Venerable Presiding Mem-ber, particularly given the fact that these people may be called upon to exercise their franchise shortly, I do not think there can be any justification for these people to be kept detained in this way. If the people decide to stay in the camps in Vavuniya of their own free will and without any pressure until they are able to move out, I would sub-mit that they should have the freedom of movement, they should have access that the normal citizens have. Their friends, their relatives, their well-wishers and others should be able to meet with them and they should be able to interact with the rest of the world. Even by their being held in these camps, they should not be treated like con-victs or even worse, like animals devoid of all their funda-mental rights. That, I submit, is illegal and unacceptable and that I think is the main complaint of the UN and the international community against the actions of the present Government, that no government has the right to keep people detained in this way depriving their fundamental rights. As far as the people being detained in the camps are concerned, Venerable Presiding Member - we know the monsoon is going to become certain very soon in these areas - I am sure they will encounter immense suffering when the monsoon sets in and the Sri Lankan Government would, I think be responsible for this situation and all the difficulties that these people will encounter because it is the Government which is compelling these people to re-main in these camps and is preventing them any freedom of movement whatever.

The other persons who are leaving the camps, Vener-able Presiding Member, have either joined relatives or host families. As per information available to us, at the moment nothing whatever is being given to these people. They are entirely the responsibility of the host family. As far as the other persons are concerned, we are told that they are being given Rs. 5,000 in cash, some utensils, some implements and food relief under the World Food Programme. Some people are being kept in transient camps in their own districts. As I mentioned before, the general view is that these camps are even worse than the camps in Vavuniya. It is our submission, Venerable Pre-siding Member, that all the people living in transit camps or transient camps in their respective districts should be able to go to their lands at the very earliest. It is also our submission, Venerable Presiding Mem-ber, that the resettlement and rehabilitation process must be done very properly. These were people who led hon-ourable lives generating their own income, living in their own houses, educating their children and leading a re-spectable happy family life. Today, they have been ren-dered destitute. They are in a state of penury. Their houses are either destroyed or damaged substantially. They have lost all their employment equipment; whether they be farmers or fishermen, they should be put on their feet again. That is a responsibility that this country owes to these people and they cannot be denied of their legiti-mate entitlement. They must be provided with the neces-sary equipment for them to commence their employment whether it be fishing, farming, animal husbandry, cottage industries or whatever and be provided with houses. The INGOs are prepared to be of considerable assistance. But, I am told, the Government is preventing the INGOs from going into these areas and working with these peo-ple. Someone from a local NGO told me yesterday that the Government Agents of Jaffna, Mullaitivu and Kili-nochchi have impressed upon the Government that the INGOs must work in these areas very freely to enable these people to be given the required assistance and that must be done. I want to make an appeal to the Govern-ment not to prevent the INGOs from going into these ar-eas and working as freely as they want. Plenty of assistance is forthcoming from India, which has already committed Rs. 500 crores and last week, a further Rs. 500 crores. Rs. 1,000 crores in Indian money would be Rs. 2,500 crores in Sri Lankan money. The UN is prepared to help. The international community - gener-ally all the countries, whether they be the European Un-ion, the USA or other countries - is prepared to help liber-ally. Therefore, there will be plenty of assistance avail-able and all these countries and institutions want to help these innocent people because they know that these inno-cent people have suffered, that these innocent civilians have suffered. That is the reason for these being avail-able, not that they want to help the Government. They want to be sure that these hundreds of thousands of inno-cent Tamil civilians who have been rendered destitute are returned to their lands and are enabled to compel normal

life again. That is why this assistance is forthcoming and I would like to impress upon the Government that they must ensure that all this assistance reaches the beneficiar-ies. I want to make an appeal to the countries concerned, to the international community concerned to ensure that all this assistance they are providing reaches the benefici-aries to the fullest degree. I am also informed that in some areas no work has commenced so far, particularly in the Kilinochchi and Mullaitivu Districts and that some of these areas still re-main unattended in any way; not even the de-mining has commenced in some areas in a proper way. We would like to appeal to the Government to ensure that in all these areas from which people were displaced, de-mining takes place and that these people are able to return to these areas at the very earliest. That is the responsibility and the duty of the Government; that is the commitment that the Gov-ernment has made to the world at large and that is the commitment which the world at large wants this Govern-ment to fulfill. Therefore, even in those areas where work has not commenced as yet, we would like to urge the Government - particularly those areas in Mullaitivu and Kilinochchi - that work must commence, de-mining must be completed early and that the people must be resettled. Venerable Presiding Member, we represent these peo-ple. Of the 15 Members of Parliament of the Northern Province, 13 come from my party. Of the six Members of Parliament in the Vanni, the area from which these people come, five come from my party. But, we are not con-sulted. We are not even allowed to visit the camps. We want the donors and the international community to take cognizance of the fact that though we requested the Gov-ernment when we met the President on the 7th of Septem-ber, two months ago, that we be allowed to go to the camps, up to now we have not been allowed to go to the camps and we are not being consulted. We are the democratically elected Representatives of these people. How can we be kept out? This is not de-mocratic governance; this is not just or good governance. We have every legitimate reason to infer that the IDPs will not benefit from all the assistance being made by all these donors unless the donors themselves take adequate care to ensure that the assistance reaches the IDPs. Venerable Presiding Member, at the last Presidential Election, President Mahinda Rajapaksa was elected by just over 50 per cent. He runs this country; he rules this country. We have 13 out of 15 members of Parliament from the Northern Province; five out of six from the Vanni. But, we have no say whatever in regard to what is happening to our people. This is not democracy; this is not democratic governance; this is not civilized govern-ance. There is one little matter I want to state, Venerable Presiding Member, before I conclude. That is, when we met the President on the 7th of September, we told him

that according to our information, at least between 10,000 and 15,000 people have been taken into custody when they came out of the conflict zone in various places, sometimes even in the camps. Even now persons in the camps are being taken into custody and we said, "The next of kin are very anxious; the parents are very anxious; the families are very anxious to know where these people are. So, kindly publish a list of these persons giving their full names, where they are being kept and put these lists up in those camps so that people can see for themselves". I am sorry to say this. As a matter of fact, my Friend, the Hon. Mavai Senathirajah, Member of Parliament has later met with even the Hon. Milinda Moragoda, the Minister of Justice and Law Reforms, in regard to this matter. We have discussed the matter with the Presidential Adviser, the Hon. Basil Rajapaksa and though two months have passed since we made that request, nothing has happened. This is unfortunate. You are keeping people in custody without their next of kin knowing as to where they are being kept. There is a duty cast upon you to make that information available to the next of kin. That is some-thing which you cannot deny. Therefore, we would ap-peal to the Government to kindly ensure that those lists are published early, that the information is made available to these families and that the families are thereby pre-vented from suffering further agony and trauma. I thank you, Venerable Presiding Member. ( ) (The Presiding Member) . .

Bismillahir Rahmanir Raheem. Nahumaduhu Salli ala Vanusalli Rasoolihil Kareem Venerable Presiding Member, I thank you for the op-portunity extended to me to participate in the Debate on the extension of the state of Emergency. Sri Lankas post-independent electoral system offers few mechanisms through which the minorities can protect their rights against the majority, thereby ensuring the majority-dominated governments to remain in power. The system of territorial representation gives the majority parties a two-thirds of the government seats whereas the upcountry Tamils, the Northern and the Eastern Tamils were defran-chised way back in 1948. State-sponsored terrorism and large-scale violation of human rights, the results of the state of emergency in Sri Lanka, can be attributed to the country's anti-terrorist legislations, such as the Public Security Ordinance, the Prevention of Terrorism Act and the Emergency Regulations. These laws enable political and security officials at all levels to participate in an il-

logical counter-campaign of terror, often more brutal and inhuman to the opponents. The Emergency Regulations that were framed under the Public Security Ordinance in 1947 enable the President to bypass the normal legisla-tive process and restrict the basic rights granted under the Constitution for national security purposes. The Preven-tion of Terrorism (Temporary Provisions) Act, No. 48 of 1979, which was enacted to deal more specifically with the civil unrest created by terrorist organizations, places limitations on the rights of the politically subordinate ethnic groups. Venerable Presiding Member, during a state of emer-gency, the President may enforce Emergency Regulations to secure the public order of the State. While the PSO and the PTA bestow powers on the President, the Emer-gency Regulations are renewed monthly to further clar-ify and specify the tactics to be used by the Government to maintain law and order and to suppress the opponents. Moving on to the suppression of freedom of speech, the censoring of the press has deprived the Sri Lankan and international community of information regarding un-folding violence in the country. Regulation 14 seeks to limit the voice of the people who have no other means of rallying round for national and international support than through public awareness. I must also emphasize about the detention of persons. The powers given to the Defence Secretary with regard to preventive detention have been broadened by re-wording the Regulations. The Defence Secretary has to be satis-fied with the material presented to him and such mate-rial can be kept for further questioning the persons who are in custody. Despite condemnation from the govern-ment and international organizations regarding extra-judicial killings, torture by the police while in custody, the Emergency Regulations provide inadequate provisions to ensure proper investigation into a death caused by se-curity personnel. When a person dies during an investi-gation, according to the Emergency Regulations, the investigation officers must file reports, the magistrate must be informed of the known fact of the death and where the body was found, a post-mortem must be con-ducted and the Deputy Inspector General of Police in charge shall determine at his discretion whether the body should to be returned to his relatives or a burial by the Government should take place. With regard to the police in this country, Venerable Pre-siding Member, there was a time when the people of this country had friendly police. Today the police is no longer people-friendly. Earlier, police officers were granted promo-tions on the basis of their years of service and transfers were granted on the number of years served in a particular police station. Those kind of promotions and installation of new officers are not being made by the Department of Police to-day, because it is highly politicized. The delay in the formation of the National Police Com-mission deprives police officers of their legitimate right to

promotions and transfers. There was a time when recom-mendations were made by the SSPs to the DIGs, who in turn passed it on to the senior DIGs, and finally, the IGP sum-mons those high officers for a meeting and approves the recommendations. Where are those recommendations? To-day, the recommendation of the politician is the main ne-cessity to transfer a police officer from one corner to an-other. Therefore, I would like to state that according to the Seventeenth Amendment to the Constitution, the National Police Commission is a must in this country. As you know, in the last Western Provincial Council Election, the police were really not interested in policing the area. In some areas, underworld people were used to - ( ) (The Presiding Member) , . . ( ) ( . - ) (The Hon. V. Puththirasigamoney - Deputy Minister of Justice ) Hon. Venerable Presiding Member, I hope you would give me my time to speak. With regard to politicizing the Police Department, I would like to invite your attention to the Provincial Coun-cil Election of the Western Province. The so-called Mou-lavis, the so-called former Members of Parliament who came on the National List and who have no ward base were advisers to the President and some people were sent to Maligawatta with the intention of terrorizing the area.

The so-called advisers were connected with the under-world. They deprived the Muslim community and the people of that area of their right to vote by terrorizing that area. The so-called kingpins like "Faji", "Baji" and Toji, who were produced all of a sudden during the time of the elections, were killed. Those were extrajudicial killings on the streets of Colombo. Those are the norms on which policing was done. The police in combat uniform were killing innocent people on the crossroads. These particular members were saying that they are connected to the President but I do not know whether they are con-nected to him; they only want to say to the world that they are connected to him. Those who are being called advisers are the godfathers of the mafia in this country today. They have been sent to the EU with a begging bowl to collect the GSP Plus. Venerable Presiding Member, the Constitution of Sri Lanka makes provision for the protection of fundamental rights in line with international standards. However, the Constitution seems to be replaced by the PTA and the PSO with the Emergency Regulations thus coming into operation repeatedly month after month with its exten-sion. It is surprising that the Emergency Laws still exist. In spite of the defeat of terrorism and the killing of Velu-pillai Prabhakaran, still there are barricades in the City of Colombo. The world is looking at Sri Lanka. If the war is over, still why are there barricades and why is peace not there for the world to see? There is no tourism; people are not coming here for investments. People are not com-ing to this country because you have shown to the world that this country is terrorized politically. Therefore, I invite your attention to this matter. All road blocks must be removed forthwith. We demand that the City of Co-lombo be opened for all and it be made free for people to move about. The Constitution states that every person has an inherent right to life and no person shall be inten-tionally or arbitrarily deprived of his life. Today what is happening in the City? People are being questioned, "Where are you going?". Some police officers ask, " , , " . , , . . . . . . The police has become a part of State terrorism. The police officers are not doing their work properly, allowing themselves to be politicized. Most of them are concerned about their own promotions, double saluting and double summersaulting in front of all politicians. Politicians must not be allowed to give promotions and transfers. Therefore, with due respect, I would like to invite your attention to the fact that there should be a code of conduct with regard to law enforcement.

I must also remind you that we supported the extension of the state of Emergency. We support the extension of the state of Emergency, but what has happened? With our sup-port to its extension, extrajudicial killings of our people have taken place. Therefore, it must be properly administered. Venerable Presiding Member, I thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to speak a few words on this De-bate. Assalamu Alaikum!
